questions.question_text:
An administrator is tasked with assembling a composite blueprint using published machines blueprints.
Which three roles can assemble a composite blueprint? (Choose three.)

A vRealize Orchestrator administrator is tasked with creating a workflow that processes sensitive information that is subject to auditing. All workflow messages must be stored in the vRealize Orchestrator database.
How can the administrator ensure that all log messages generated by the workflow are stored in the database?

choices.B: Use System.log() when printing out messages.
choices.C: Configure SQL plugin to write to the database directly.
choices.A: Configure a DEBUG level for the vRealize Orchestrator server.
choices.D: Use Server.log() when printing out messages.

questions.question_text:
A vRealize Automation administrator is installing vRealize Automation using the installation wizard. The administrator cannot see any Windows servers in which to install IaaS components.
Which agent must be installed on the IaaS Windows servers?

comments.content: Good link @jasonv. Thank you and yes Answer B is correct.

discussion.content: Definitely D "BuildingMachine". Its primarily utilized when applying customizable VM workflows. https://docs.vmware.com/en/vRealize-Automation/7.5/vrealize-automation-75-extensibility.pdf

comments.content: I would go with D*. Sorry for the typo!

discussion.content: Major hint is provided in the question itself: "During VM Provisioning" so it has to be BuildingMachine. I would go with "A".

Should be A.
On BuildingMachine the VM does not exist on the hypervisor yet.

MachineProvisioned
"Prepare for the machine to be created on the hypervisor.Create
a configuration management database (CMDB) record, call out
to an external system to assign an IP address to a machine,
and then during machine disposal, use
WFStubMachineDisposing to return the IP address to the pool."

Refer to the linked document.
A seems like a valid option too, as it's after D, so the machine should be ready to go?

questions.question_text: During VM provisioning, which Event Broker state would an administrator use to execute a workflow to add CPU to a virtual machine?

choices.B: Communicate with hypervisor and cloud endpoints

questions.question_text: What is the role of the Proxy Agent?

discussion.content:
A is correct

Proxy agents collect data, such as virtual machine data, from the hypervisors.

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Validated-Design/5.0/com.vmware.vvd.sddc-design.doc/GUID-6158120D-C982-4F27-B1D3-4BCB46254FCF.html

comments.content: D... I would have gone with vCenter endpoints as the referenced material suggest.

discussion.content:
Answer A

https://docs.vmware.com/en/vRealize-Automation/7.6/com.vmware.vra.install.upgrade.doc/GUID-D491FFB3-D195-4E98-979E-498119FB674A.html

The vRealize Automation IaaS Proxy Agent is a windows service used to communicate with specific infrastructure endpoints. 
Could be vSphere, Hyper-V, XenServer, XenDesktop...
A is the right answer I guess

This link shows it is vSphere.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Validated-Design/5.0/com.vmware.vvd.sddc-design.doc/GUID-6158120D-C982-4F27-B1D3-4BCB46254FCF.html

To provision and manage virtual machines, the proxy agent sends requests for resource virtualization to the hypervisor, that is, to vSphere.

The reference link states "The vRealize Automation IaaS Proxy Agent is a windows service used to communicate with specific infrastructure endpoints. In this design, the vSphere Proxy agent is utilized to communicate with vCenter." Did not mention anything about cloud endpoints, so not sure if C is correct.
